title: 105_hr1971
content: The Act titled "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" includes provisions for debarment and other sanctions. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" includes amendments to Section 8902a of title 5, United States Code, regarding the definition of "should know" and expanding the subsections covered. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" amends Section 8902a of title 5, United States Code, to specify that the Office of Personnel Management must bar certain healthcare providers from participating in federal programs. This includes providers currently suspended or excluded from government procurement activities. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" amends Section 8902a of title 5, United States Code, to bar healthcare providers with revoked, suspended, or surrendered licenses from participating in federal programs. This also applies to providers owned by individuals convicted of certain offenses. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" prohibits individuals with revoked licenses or certain convictions from participating in federal healthcare programs. This includes entities owned by individuals involved in offenses described in the Act. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" prohibits providers from charging for health care services or supplies that are excessive or of poor quality. Providers found to have committed such acts may face consequences as determined by the Office. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" prohibits providers from charging for excessive or poor quality health care services. Consequences for providers found guilty may include debarment under specific conditions outlined in the Act. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" allows for debarment of providers under specific conditions, with a process for notice and hearing before any adverse determination is made. The Act "Federal Employees Health Benefits Provider Integrity Amendments of 1997" allows for debarment of providers under specific conditions, with a minimum debarment period of 3 years, except as provided in certain cases. The Office will provide notice and an opportunity for a hearing to individuals facing adverse determinations. A hearing officer designated by the Director will conduct the hearing, ensuring due process rights are upheld. Requests for a hearing must be filed within the specified period and according to Office regulations. Any provider can seek review of a final decision through the United States District Court within 60 days after the decision is issued. The Director of the Office will file a certified copy of the transcript of the record and other evidence in response to the appeal. The court has the power to make a decision based on the pleadings and evidence presented. The United States District Court can affirm, modify, or set aside the Office's decision based on the evidence. The court can only do so if there is not substantial evidence to support the Office's findings or if the Office abused its discretion. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, with exceptions for specific misconduct occurring after that date. Paragraph (1)(B) of section 8902a(d) of title 5, United States Code, applies to charges violating section 8904(b) for items or services provided after the enactment of this Act. Paragraph (3) of section 8902a(g) applies to debarments based on convictions occurring after the enactment of this Act. Section 1128B(f)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to remove the health insurance program under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code.
